clean_content:
Definition / general

* Osteosarcoma constitutes a primary malignant bone neoplasm in which tumor cells produce immature (osteoid) bone* Osteosarcoma of maxillofacial region is called gnathic osteosarcoma

Essential features

* Jaw is the fourth most common site (gnathic osteosarcoma) and primarily occurs in the third and fourth decade of life ([Clin Pract 2024;14:965](38921255))* Distinct clinical and biological behavior as compared to osteosarcoma of the extremities* Neoplastic spindle cells with osteoid deposition and variable cellular (osteoblastic, chondroblastic and fibroblastic) differentiation ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2018;17:38](29382992))

Terminology

* Osteosarcoma (WHO recommended)

ICD coding

* ICD-O
  + [9180/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf#page=87) - osteosarcoma, NOS+ [9186/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf#page=87) - conventional osteosarcoma* ICD-11: [2B51.0](https://icd.who.int/browse/2024-01/mms/en#1102292672) - osteosarcoma of bone and articular cartilage of jaw

Epidemiology

* Jaw bones account for 6% of osteosarcoma cases with mandible being the most common site* More common in third and fourth decades of life, as compared to axial osteosarcoma* No sex predilection ([J Int Med Res 2020;48:300060520971488](33342340))

Sites

* Mandible (alveolar ridge) is the most common location, followed by maxilla (antrum) ([Front Oncol 2023;13:1006622](37035145))

Pathophysiology

* Chromosomal instability
  + Hallmark of osteosarcoma, chromosomal segregation errors during cell division (chromoanagenesis; chromothripsis / chromoplexy) leads to supernumerary chromosome that results in chromosomal instability* Target genes involved in the development of osteosarcoma
    + *TP53* and *RB1* genes commonly mutated (high grade osteosarcoma)+ *MDM2* and *CDK4* gene amplifications (low grade and dedifferentiated osteosarcomas) ([Dis Markers 2021;2021:8818363](33747256), [Crit Rev Oncol Hematol 2020;156:103126](33113487))

Etiology

* Most cases are sporadic in nature* Ionizing radiation, pre-existing Paget disease of the bone, fibrous dysplasia and chronic osteomyelitis are important risk factors ([Clin Pract 2024;14:965](38921255))

Diagrams / tables

* See [Molecular / cytogenetics images](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/URL.html#molecularcytogeneticsimagessection)

Clinical features

* Localized jaw swelling with pain and paresthesia (most common presentation) and tooth displacement or loss and misalignment ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2018;17:38](29382992))* Nasal obstruction and epistaxis (commonly in maxillary bone tumors) ([J Neurol Surg B Skull Base 2021;82:e138](34306929))* Facial disfigurement, hard tender swelling of maxilla with bone destruction ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2021;87:106425](34560593))

Diagnosis

* Imaging
  + Computed tomography (CT) scan is particularly useful for assessing biopsy and staging+ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is preferred for intraosseous tumor extension and soft tissue involvement ([Dentomaxillofac Radiol 2020;49:20190202](31642708))* Open biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis* Limited biopsies may not contain osteoid deposition areas and therefore pose a diagnostic challenge

Laboratory

* Not clinically relevant

Radiology description

* Imaging findings depend on amount of mineralized matrix produced by the tumor* Most cases are mixed radiolucent and radio dense, with osteodestructive growth pattern and soft tissue extension (suggesting high grade lesions), classic periosteal reaction (Codman triangle and sunburst appearance) ([Dentomaxillofac Radiol 2020;49:20190202](31642708))* Widening of the periodontal ligament space of the involved teeth due to tumor infiltration

Lytic and destructive  
lesion in the left maxillary  
tuber and molar tooth  
area with root resorption

Prognostic factors

* Size, cranial / brain extension and distant metastases at the time of presentation* Residual disease (postoperative) ([Am J Rhinol Allergy 2021;35:132](32954838))

Case reports

* 34 year old woman presented with gingival swelling with loosening of the lower right canine ([Clin Case Rep 2023;11:e7198](37064745))* 45 year old man presented with painless oral swelling for 5 months ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2022;93:106909](35339036))* 47 year old woman presented with painless quickly increasing swelling near anterior mandible for 3 months ([Cureus 2024;16:e53713](38455794))* 62 year old woman presented with large painful swelling on right mandibular area for 2 months ([J Egypt Natl Canc Inst 2023;35:30](37718329))* 65 year old man presented with difficulty of swallowing and pain on right side of face for 3 months ([Medicina 2022;58:1141](36143818))

Treatment

* Treatment of choice; surgical resection with clear margins (particular mandible and maxilla)* Slight improvement in survival has been observed with (neo)adjuvant chemotherapy in cases involving positive margins, tumor recurrence and high grade tumors ([Medicine 2019;98:e13875](30608407))

Clinical images

Swelling in left  
premaxillary  
region with upper  
lip protrusion

Gross description

* Bony hard intramedullary tumor with frequent soft tissue extension ([Clin Pract 2024;14:965](38921255))* Cut surface shows shiny cartilaginous to friable and hemorrhagic areas ([Cancer 1982;49:1679](6950802))

Gross images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Gross examination left hemimandibulectomy](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaOSthumbimg04.jpg)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11202223/figure/clinpract-14-00077-f003/)

Left hemimandibulectomy

Frozen section description

Not found

Frozen section images

Not found

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Tumor comprises highly atypical cells and associated immature and lace-like neoplastic osteoid deposition (conventional osteosarcoma)* Extent of matrix deposition ranges from focal immature osteoid to heavily mineralized sclerotic bone formation* Entrapped pre-existing trabeculae infiltrated by tumor cells and neoplastic bone (osteoid) → osteodestructive and permeation of marrow spaces* Pseudo capsule (rim of periosteum around the invasive edge after cortical destruction)* Predominant matrix determines the conventional osteosarcoma subtypes
          + Chondroblastic osteosarcoma: conventional osteosarcoma with predominant cartilage differentiation (loose basophilic intercellular substance with cells lying in lacunar spaces), common in jaw bones ([J Cancer Res Ther 2018;14:471](29516945))+ Osteoblastic osteosarcoma: abundant tumor osteoid production → from early dense fibrillar eosinophilic substance to lace-like pattern and variable mineralization and ossification (tumor bone formation)+ Fibroblastic osteosarcoma: confluent proliferation of atypical spindle cells (mimicking fibrosarcoma) with high grade cytologic atypia and irregular mineralized matrix deposition* Low grade central osteosarcoma and parosteal osteosarcoma (low grade osteosarcoma): abundant fibroblastic stromal component with embedded irregular and interlacing bone trabeculae* Low cellularity and minimal cytologic atypia

Microscopic (histologic) images

Positive stains

* [SATB2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssatb2.html): nuclear staining in tumor cells (detects osteoblastic differentiation) ([J Pathol Transl Med 2022;56:270](36128863))* [MDM2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmdm2.html): nuclear staining in tumor cells (helps in differentiating low grade osteosarcoma from benign fibro-osseous lesions)* [CDK4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscdk4.html): nuclear staining in tumor cells (helps in differentiating low grade osteosarcoma from benign fibro-osseous lesions) ([Mod Pathol 2011;24:624](21336260))

Negative stains

* [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html) ([Appl Immunohistochem Mol Morphol 2012;20:445](22495377))* [EMA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html) ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2012;16:233](22923896))* [p63](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp63.html) ([Pathol Res Pract 2022;229:153733](34929597))* [p40](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp40.html) ([Pathol Res Pract 2022;229:153733](34929597))

Electron microscopy description

* Not clinically relevant

Electron microscopy images

* Not clinically relevant

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* *TP53* and *RB1* gene mutation (most common) ([Dis Markers 2021;2021:8818363](33747256))* *MDM2* and *CDK4* gene amplifications

Molecular / cytogenetics images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Genome wide copy number alterations](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaOSthumbimg05.jpg)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11424644/figure/Fig1/)

Genome wide copy number alterations

Videos

Not available

Sample pathology report

* Posterior mandibular mass, biopsy:
  + Conventional osteosarcoma, osteoblastic type, high grade (see comment)+ Comment: The biopsy shows a malignant neoplasm that comprises cellular areas of oval to spindle cells with marked cytologic atypia, nuclear pleomorphism and brisk mitotic activity. Areas of fibrillar eosinophilic material deposition (osteoid) by tumor cells are seen. The findings are consistent with osteosarcoma with osteoblastic differentiation. Radiological correlation is advised.

Differential diagnosis

* [Sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html):
  + Bleeding ulcer on alveolar ridge, limited jaw opening and pain, chronic sinus discharge (oral cavity), nasal obstruction and epistaxis (maxillary involvement) and scalp skin ulcer with underlying bone destruction (temporal region)+ Mandibular ramus (most common site), followed by buccal region, paranasal sinuses (particularly maxilla) and scalp skin+ Male predilection+ Peak in fourth to sixth decades of life+ Microscopy: sheets of spindle cells arranged in fascicular pattern, hyperchromatic nuclei and conspicuous nucleoli; absent keratinization and epithelial nests ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2019;23:163](31110445))+ Positive [p40](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp40.html) and [CK5/6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck5and6.html) immunostains are diagnostic for SCC ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2019;23:163](31110445))* [Fibrous dysplasia (FD)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/bonefibrousdysplasia.html):
    + Involves facial bones (mandible and maxilla) and skull (particularly frontal bone)+ Occurs in children and young adults (second to third decade)+ Monostotic forms (involves one bone) and polyostotic (multiple bones)+ Presentation includes painless jaw swelling, nasal obstruction (maxilla involvement) and scalp swelling (cranial bone involvement)+ Characterized by *GNAS* mutation+ Microscopy: mixture of fibrous tissue (mostly hypocellular and contains bland spindle cells) and irregular curvilinear trabeculae of woven bone without osteoblastic rimming ([J Clin Med 2023;12:4100](37373793))+ Fibrous dysplasia of jaw can show osteoblastic rimming and lamellar bone differentiation as it matures+ Mimic low grade osteosarcomas (parosteal and low grade central) due to lack of cytologic atypia, fibrous tissue and lamellar bone+ *[MDM2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmdm2.html)* gene amplification by FISH or positive staining of [MDM2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmdm2.html) and [CDK4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscdk4.html) immunostains might aid in differentiating these lesions ([Mod Pathol 2010;23:1279](20601938))* [Central giant cell granuloma (CGCG)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacentralgiantcellgranuloma.html):
      + Exclusively involves the jaw (particularly anterior mandible)+ Young age (less than 30 years) with female predilection+ Imaging: solid and cystic tumor with prominent calcification and contrast enhancing cyst wall (> 90% of cases)+ Microscopy: tumor with lobulated architecture, lobules separated by thin fibrous septa that may contain osteoid or woven bone; lobules contain spindle to polygonal shaped mononuclear stromal cells and admixed multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells; the background contains hemorrhage and hemosiderin pigment ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2020;24:413](33967473))* [Conventional chondrosarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/bonechondrosarcoma.html):
        + Mostly involves maxilla and nasal septum versus mandible+ Slight predilection to middle aged men+ Imaging: osteolytic (high T2 weighted signal intensity) lesion, ranging from well defined to aggressively destructive with stippled to irregular opaque masses, best seen on CT scan+ Microscopy: tumor exhibits lobular architecture with permeative growth pattern; oval to polygonal cells with small uniform nuclei, evenly dispersed chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli within lacunar spaces surrounded by basophilic matrix (well differentiated tumor; resembles hyaline cartilage); high cellularity with irregular distribution, multinucleation and nuclear pleomorphism and brisk mitotic activity correspond to higher grade (mimics chondroblastic type osteosarcoma) ([Diagnostics (Basel) 2023;13:3026](37835769))* [Osteoblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/boneosteoblastoma.html):
          + Often involves body of mandible (intraosseous or periosteal) among craniofacial bones+ Rare tumor, occurs in second to third decades of life with slight female predominance+ Presents with localized swelling and pain+ Imaging: circumscribed round (radiolucent to radiopaque) lesion up to 20 mm diameter without sclerotic rim or periosteal reaction+ Microscopy: anastomosing trabeculae of bone and osteoid, rimmed by osteoblasts with a background of rich fibrovascular stroma; lack of cortex infiltration, nuclear pleomorphism, atypical or brisk mitoses distinguish it from osteoblastic type conventional osteosarcoma ([Virchows Arch 2020;476:455](31768625))* [Cementoblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacementoblastoma.html):
            + Develops on apical third of the root (permanent first molar in posterior mandible), mandibular premolar and maxillary molar are second most common sites of involvement+ Characteristically causes slow painful expansion of jaw+ Occurs in second and third decades of life, no sex predilection+ Imaging: a well defined mixed density lesion within the root of the associated tooth; characteristic radiolucent rim in continuity of the periodontal ligament usually present+ Microscopy: dense cellular cementum mass fused with resorbed surface of the root (resembles bone) with prominent reversal lines; peripheral radiating new matrix deposition along with plump cementoblasts and cementoclasts within immature vascularized fibrous tissue (mimic primary bone tumor) ([Oncol Lett 2016;11:3761](27313689), [Radiol Case Rep 2024;19:2085](38523691))* [Mucosal melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumormelanocyticmucosalmelanoma.html):
              + Head and neck, nasal cavity / septum and maxillary sinus are common sites+ Nasal endoscopy: pigmented polypoidal mass+ Microscopy: polymorphic tumor cell population: spindled, epithelioid, rhabdoid, clear and undifferentiated cell morphology+ [HMB45](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainshmb45.html)+ ([Head Neck Pathol 2016;10:298](26753505))* [Odontogenic sarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaameloblasticfibrosarcoma.html):
                + Mixed odontogenic neoplasm with malignant ectomesenchymal component+ Involves mandible (particularly posterior region)+ Locally aggressive expansile lesions with or without pain or tooth displacement+ Imaging: rounded (benign appearing) radiolucent lesion with cortical expansion and destruction+ Microscopy: epithelial (benign) component resembles dental lamina line strands or large islands of odontogenic epithelium+ Peripheral cells with nuclear palisading and reverse polarity without stellate reticulum+ Ectomesenchymal (malignant) component: hypercellular with varying cytologic atypia and mitoses (fibrosarcoma-like areas)+ Dysplastic dentin with or without enamel matrix can be present (ameloblastic fibrodentinosarcoma or ameloblastic fibroodontosarcoma) ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2020;24:157](32508466))

Additional references

* [Oral Oncology Reports 2022;10:100479](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S277290602400325X)
